;;P;;也许它;总是好得令人难以置信。 2023 年的重大经济故事是美国看似无痛的通货紧缩，尽管增长仍保持弹性，但消费者价格压力却在消退，这支撑了股价的飙升。可惜的是，2024 年迄今为止的故事并不那么令人愉快。经济增长依然强劲，但部分原因是通胀看起来更加棘手。美联储面临是否开始降息的两难选择；投资者必须面对这样一个现实：货币政策几乎肯定会比几个月前预期的更长时间保持紧缩。

;;
;;
;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-1f0x4sl e1tt35bk0">;最新的麻烦数据来自于 4 月 10 日发布的 3 月份通胀率高于预期。分析师此前预计，剔除食品和能源成本的核心消费者价格指数（<小>;CPI;）将环比上涨0.3%。相反，它上涨了0.4%。尽管这听起来可能并没有太大的超调，但这已经是;CPI;读数连续第三个月超出预期。如果继续下去，目前的通胀率将比去年同期巩固在 4% 以上，是美联储 2% 目标（基于略有不同的通胀指标）的两倍（见图表）。

;

;早在 12 月份，在乐观情绪达到顶峰时，大多数投资者就已经预计今年会降息六到七次。此后他们降低了这些期望。在最新通胀数据公布后的几分钟内，市场定价就转变为意味着今年只会降息一两次——这是一个巨大的变化。现在美联储可能不会在 11 月总统大选前降息，这对现任总统乔·拜登来说将是一个打击。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;杰罗姆·鲍威尔，美联储主席一直保持一贯立场。他一直坚持央行将采取依赖数据的方式来制定货币政策。但他并没有因为新数据而上下波动，而是建议保持耐心。今年年初，即使在连续六个月基本良性的价格变动之后，美联储仍希望在开始降息之前对通胀正在走低抱有更多信心。这种谨慎可能显得有些过分。今天看起来完全合适。

;

;市场定价的波动也改变了美联储相对于市场的定位。去年年底，当投资者预计今年将有多达七次降息时，官员们只预测了三次，显得鹰派。在不到一个月前发布的最新预测中，官员们仍预计将削减三笔，现在看来显得鸽派。美联储将在 6 月份更新其预测。

;

;与此同时，美联储将不仅仅关注 ;CPI;。其首选的通胀指标——核心个人消费支出价格指数(;PCE;)将在几周内发布，预计3月份环比接近0.3%。一些推高;CPI;的项目，特别是机动车保险和医疗服务，在;PCE;计算中的定义有所不同。显示工资增长持续放缓的数据也可能让美联储感到安慰。

;

;尽管如此，试图通过指出这一点来解释令人不安的数字或者这个数据怪异让人想起2021年，当时否认通胀的人认为价格快速上涨只是一种暂时现象。今天的总体结论是，尽管增长仍然令人印象深刻，但现在似乎正在突破经济的供应限制，因此正在转化为持续的通胀压力。这就需要紧缩而不是宽松的货币政策。当通胀数据更加配合时，美联储已经对降息持谨慎态度，现在可能会更加谨慎。 ;■;

;;C;;alm 讨论;关于跨性别医学的情况很少见。英国医生希拉里·卡斯 (Hilary Cass) 表示：“在医疗保健领域，专业人士很少有如此害怕公开讨论他们的观点的。” 4 月 10 日，她受英格兰国家卫生服务中心委托发表了一份 388 页的报告，评估了支持和反对对跨性别儿童进行治疗的证据。其结论将在大西洋两岸引起反响，那里的护理标准差异很大。

;

;有争议的治疗方法包括青春期阻滞剂、跨性别激素和（很少）手术。青春期阻滞剂是延迟青春期开始的药物。跨性别激素会刺激异性特征的发展：雌激素使男性乳房变大，睾酮使女性肌肉更大、声音更低沉等等。“没有可靠的证据基础”表明这些好处《卡斯评论》称，向儿童提供此类治疗的好处大于其危害。许多研究已经发表，但它们往往“质量很差”。有些人从微小样本中得出结论。有些缺乏对照组，因此无法将接受治疗的患者的结果与未接受治疗的患者的结果进行比较。为观察长期影响所做的努力太少。一些诊所甚至拒绝收集此类数据的尝试。卡斯博士告诉;BBC;：“我们为年轻人提供可能改变生活的治疗，却不知道他们成年后会发生什么，这是不寻常的。”
;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在富裕国家，跨性别儿童的照顾方法现在分为三大类：自由放任、严厉和谨慎。自由放任的做法在美国的蓝色州很常见，它认为，如果孩子们认为自己是异性，并且迫切希望调整自己的身体以适应这种感觉，那么应该允许他们这样做。支持者说，如果拒绝这种“性别肯定护理”，他们的生活将受到破坏，他们可能会考虑结束这种生活。一些活动人士用强硬的语言补充说，只有跨性别者才可能反对。美国儿科学会是一个国家机构，支持向未成年人提供青春期阻滞剂和跨性别激素，同时评估新证据。

;

;严厉的做法是应该禁止此类治疗。这在美国的红色州很常见，一些政客煽动对跨性别者的反感以赢得选票。一些州将禁止治疗与对提供治疗的医生的严厉处罚结合起来。佛罗里达州威胁要判处他们五年监禁；爱达荷州，十岁。德克萨斯州试图调查为孩子寻求这种照顾的父母是否适合成为父母；尽管这件事现在已被法庭审理。总共有 22 个美国州禁止或限制对青少年的跨性别护理，其中大多数是最近才实施的。

;

;这种谨慎的做法为政策提供了依据丹麦、芬兰、挪威、瑞典和现在的英格兰强调需要更多证据。没有人知道为什么在过去十年中被认定为跨性别者的儿童数量激增。在给他们服用可以使他们永久不育且无法体验性高潮的药物之前，医生应该探索其他干预措施。许多跨性别认同的孩子后来放弃了，有时意识到自己是同性恋。许多人还患有抑郁症或患有自闭症。卫生保健提供者应该就这些问题提供咨询，即使孩子需要，也不要急于采取更具侵入性的治疗。因此，英国的;NHS;现在仅作为临床试验的一部分提供青春期阻滞剂。 《卡斯评论》指出，应仅向 16 岁以上的儿童提供跨性别激素，并且要“极其谨慎”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;作为; 《经济学人》;;之前曾争论过;，谨慎的做法是最明智的。跨性别者应始终受到尊重和善意对待，成年人应该可以自由地对自己的身体做出决定。但正如卡斯博士总结的那样，必须防止“未经证实的方法渗透到临床实践中”。在一个政治争议如此激烈的领域，这可能很难。在卫生系统中，这也可能更加困难，因为私人医生每次干预都会获得报酬，因此有动力满足患者的要求。尽管如此，医疗当局有责任根据确凿的证据提供治疗。;■;

;此类措施可能是毁灭性的。 2018年，美国财政部宣布正在考虑指定拉脱维亚的; ablv ;银行，这是帮助朝鲜躲避制裁的票房。由于担心被指定类似，其他机构开始从; ablv ; insse中撤回资金，银行在几天之内就倒塌了。温和的次要制裁已被用来通过对与之打交道的外国银行的高额罚款来削减伊朗公司。 >;美国将这一范围覆盖归于其货币的角色，因此其银行体系在国际金融中发挥了作用。拒绝遵守规定的外国银行面临的最终威胁是它们失去清算美元交易的能力，而这些交易最终必须由在美联储拥有账户的人来处理。这就是美元在贸易，跨境支付和资本市场上的主导地位，这实际上使受害者从全球金融体系中消除。

;Movers and flippers

;

;Taken together, the demographic characteristics in YouGov's surveys do a good job of distinguishing Mr Biden's voters from Mr Trump's. Our full model, which also includes variables like home ownership, marital status, sexual orientation and residing in a city versus a rural area, can intuit the voting intentions of three-quarters of respondents based on other data about them. If you input your own profile, there is roughly a 75% chance that you support the candidate whom the model deems the likelier choice. But identifying the narrow sliver of voters who will account for changes from the results of 2020—those who are either switching between voting and not voting, or plan to flip from one candidate to the other—is far harder.

;

;The two percentage points of vote share that Mr Trump has gained since 2020 come from three sources. The largest group is people who supported Mr Biden last time, but are now undecided or backing minor candidates, who outnumber those making the same shift from Mr Trump's camp. These voters account for 0.9 points of Mr Trump's two-point improvement. Undecided former Biden voters are slightly younger, more likely to be black or female and less likely to have attended college than repeat Biden voters are.

;Mr Trump also enjoys a narrow edge among people entering or returning to the major-party electorate. The share of respondents who say they did not vote for either him or Mr Biden in 2020 but have now settled on Mr Trump is 3.7%, slightly above the 3.3% who are choosing Mr Biden. This group adds another 0.3 percentage points to Mr Trump's tally.

;

;The final group, swing voters, is the smallest but also the most impactful. Because people who flip between the two major-party candidates both subtract a vote from one side and add one to the other, they matter twice as much as do those who switch between a candidate and not voting at all. Such voters are rare—just 3% of respondents fall into this category—but Mr Trump is winning two-thirds of them. With 2% of participants shifting from Mr Biden to Mr Trump versus just 1% doing the opposite, swing voters contribute a full percentage point to Mr Trump's two-way vote share.

;

;In today's polarised political climate, with the same nominees running in both 2020 and 2024, who could possibly change their mind? One political cliché supported by YouGov's data is that swing voters are far more focused on “kitchen-table” issues than on the culture-war subjects that animate reliable partisans. Among repeat Biden voters, the topics most often cited as most important are climate and the environment; civil rights, abortion and guns are also among the leaders. Immigration ranks second on the corresponding list for repeat Trump voters, as well as conventional Republican topics like taxes and national security. In contrast, Biden-Trump swing voters are most likely to list inflation as their top issue, followed by “jobs and the economy”. Health care ranks third for them and first for Trump-Biden voters, suggesting that Mr Biden might be well-advised to make defending the health-care reform passed when he was Barack Obama's vice-president a core campaign issue.

;

;Mr Biden has also lost ground among conservative-leaning African-Americans. By 2020 Mr Trump had already alienated virtually the entire left-of-centre electorate: among self-described liberals who recall supporting a major-party candidate that year, Mr Biden won at least 90% within each racial group. In contrast, although Mr Trump won 94% of the two-party vote among white conservatives and 79% of Hispanic ones, he actually lost black voters who identify as conservative, receiving just 35% of their support. This year, Mr Trump is on the brink of winning this group outright, with a 46% share among decided voters. A similar trend applies to the 23% of black respondents registered to vote who say that they disapprove of Mr Biden's job performance. Of this group, 9% have already decided to flip to Mr Trump after backing Mr Biden last time, and a further 27% say they voted for Mr Biden in 2020 but are now undecided, supporting a third-party candidate or do not plan to vote.

;

;The most intriguing pattern in YouGov's data, however, is probably an equally powerful factor that has nothing to do with ideology.与坚定的党派相比，摇摆不定的选民生孩子年龄在 18 岁以下的可能性要大得多：从拜登转向特朗普的选民中，有 47% 的选民目前正在抚养孩子，而从另一党派转向特朗普的选民中，有 40% 目前正在抚养孩子，而重复拜登选民的这一比例为 22%选民和19%的支持特朗普的选民。 And once the effects of race and parenthood are combined, the disparities are striking.

;

;Family matters

;

;Among people who backed one of the two leading candidates in 2020 and plan to do so this year, 10% of non-white respondents with school-age children are flipping from Mr Biden to Mr Trump; another 3% are switching from Mr Trump to Mr Biden. The corresponding figures for the rest of the electorate are 2% and 1%. These switchers do not seem to have any demographic factor in common besides their race and children. In a statistical model accounting for 15 other variables—including sex, education, income, religion and location—being a non-white parent is the second-best predictor (after being young) of being a Biden 2020-Trump 2024 swing voter.

;

;Of the 183 non-white parents in YouGov's surveys who say they are switching from Mr Biden to Mr Trump, just 3% list education as the election's most important issue, compared with 48% citing inflation or the economy. This suggests that they are feeling squeezed more than voters who do not have children. It may also suggest that there is something about raising children.

;

;There is no shortage of possible culprits, from concern about school curriculums to a parental reaction against progressive ideas on gender. But one thing that affected non-white parents of schoolchildren disproportionately was public policy during the covid-19 pandemic. Lockdowns were unusually difficult for parents raising children, who had to watch their kids while schools were closed. And although lockdowns began during Mr Trump's presidency, they persisted well into Mr Biden's term, after the advent of covid vaccines made them harder to justify. Teachers' unions, allied with the Democratic Party, embraced school closures despite evidence from other countries or concerns about learning loss. Moreover, the expansion of federal transfer payments during the pandemic, which were particularly generous for parents, also began under Mr Trump and ended under Mr Biden.

;

;Non-white students were much likelier than white ones to have had fully remote education during the pandemic. And non-white parents were unusually prone to have jobs that required showing up in person. Most white working-class parents who were upset about lockdowns were already solidly Republican by 2020, limiting the number of voters from this group available to defect from Mr Biden. In contrast, the president won large majorities of non-white voters that year, so angering them was far more electorally costly. Mr Biden faces a parent trap in November. ;■;

;

;But then Rose was clever. And for a time—after the ball gowns but before the bombs—she had excelled. She'd only agreed to that gown so that her parents would let her apply to Oxford. ;

;He certainly had not meant to. Rose had been born into that English class for whom ignorance was less an accidental state than an ideal. At Miss Ironside's School for Girls, mistresses instructed the girls less in science than in sitting up straight: getting the right answer mattered far less than getting “Mr Right”. At home, Rose was expected to dress for dinner, curtsy to guests and hunt both deer and a husband. And above all she had to do “the season”, that “upper-class version of a puberty rite” as the writer Jessica Mitford called it, when four hundred girls in pearls curtsied before the queen. Or, as Princess Margaret put it, when “every tart in London” did. Rose was repelled: it was no more than a pornographic marriage market.

;

;Oxford, by contrast, had felt so modern. Her female tutor, Peter Ady, particularly so. Peter had breeches, Burmese ancestry, dark eyes, a boy's name (her mother had hoped for a son) and a habit of passionately kissing other women on the mouth. ;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And for a time she was.与彼得一起，与社会变革。 Later, after Rose had been arrested—first for burgling her father's house, then for stealing art from another one, and for that hijacking—people would wonder why an Oxford-educated deb had turned to terrorism.这是一个错误的问题：尽管她有优势，但她并不是一个叛逆者，而是因为这些优势。牛津将她从性别和阶级中解放出来。 There, she had stopped curtsying and started to wear men's shirts.她和一个朋友甚至把自己伪装成男人（戴着假发、戴眼镜、咕哝着）来破坏全男性的牛津联盟。 Though her liberation was not total: when the ;BBC ;came to interview her about it, Rose meekly made them tea.

;

;Still, the revolution was coming. And when Bloody Sunday happened in 1972, and 13 civilians were killed by British soldiers, Rose decided to hasten it along. She turned against Britain—the “filthy enemy”—and became a militant. Whereupon her upper-class education suddenly came into its own. All that hunting and shooting was ideal rifle practice for a terrorist. Years of crawling on her belly stalking deer made her the perfect guerrilla fighter. ;On April 26th, 1974, a little after 9.15pm, a car drove up to Russborough House in Ireland. Inside the house were Sir Alfred and Lady Beit and an expensive art collection. ;;W;;HEN IT comes; to architectural accomplishments, humans like to think they stand at the top of the pyramid.这就是低估了社会性昆虫的惊人成就：白蚁筑起摩天大楼的巢穴，蜜蜂则塑造出令人着迷的几何蜂巢。 The true master builders of the insect world, however, are the hundreds of species of stingless bee, native to the tropics and subtropics, which weave combs of unparalleled variety and intricacy inside hollow tree trunks or other cavities.

;

;Now a group of evolutionary biologists led by Viviana Di Pietro at ;KU ;Leuven, in Belgium, reports that, like humans, these tiny-brained creatures are capable of building according to different architectural traditions which are then handed down over generations.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The finding, published in ;Current ;;Biology;, is the clearest demonstration yet of culture in insects living in the wild. This unlikely fusion of terms would once have been thought impossible, says behavioural biologist Andrew Whiten of the University of St Andrews, who was not involved in the research. “Less than a century ago, culture was thought to be uniquely human.”

;

;To collect their data, Ms Di Pietro and her colleagues observed more than 400 colonies of the stingless bee species ;Scaptotrigona depilis; in a large apiary in Brazil over two extended periods in 2022 and 2023. Around 95% of the colonies exhibited combs built up in horizontal layers, like tiered wedding cakes, while the remainder adopted a spiral structure. In each case the tradition was maintained over many generations of worker bees.

;

;Since ;S. depilis; shows a strong preference for a horizontal-layer comb structure, it is surprising that spiral combs occur at all. Capturing the insects' behaviour on video, the team established that there was no difference in average cell-building rate between the two styles, and hence no efficiency advantage to either.

;

;In order to rule out a genetic explanation for the different styles, the researchers transplanted workers from colonies that built in one tradition to colonies that built in the other, having first emptied the host structures of their indigenous adults. The imported workers soon switched to the local style, which was then perpetuated by the colony's own larvae as they eventually matured into workers.

;

;Tom Wenseleers, who runs the lab in which Ms Di Pietro is a doctoral student, hypothesised that the bees may switch styles as a way of coping with the build-up of minuscule construction errors made by their predecessors. Such a process, in which multiple organisms indirectly affect each other's behaviour through the traces they leave on their environment, is known as stigmergy. To test whether stigmergy was in fact responsible for the stylistic schism between bee colonies, the researchers introduced a hint of helicity to otherwise perfect horizontal-layer combs, and found that it did indeed prompt the bees to switch to building spirals. That is strong evidence in favour of Dr Wenseleers's hypothesis.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;These results have left observers of animal culture abuzz, as they suggest that stingless bees can transmit different building traditions across generations without individuals needing to be instructed by their peers. This is a more expansive way of thinking about culture, which is often rigidly defined as behaviour directly transmitted from individual to individual until it becomes characteristic of a group.

;

;For Dr Whiten, the new finding indicates that more complex animal behaviours—the building of dams by beavers or nests by chimpanzees, for instance—may also have arisen through such indirect transmission. Though it is too early to know for certain, say scientists, it is possible that some human traditions could have stigmergic roots too.

;

;Bees may not be done confounding expectations. In recent laboratory experiments with bumblebees, Lars Chittka, a behavioural ecologist at Queen Mary, University of London, found that they were capable of learning cumulatively—that is, adopting and expanding upon the innovations of previous generations. The team trained “demonstrator bees” to open a complicated two-step puzzle box (in which blue and red tabs had to be pushed out of the way to reveal a solution of sucrose), and then observed other insects learning the right technique from the demonstrators. Such cumulative culture, which does require social learning, was previously thought to be unique to humans. It may be long past time to make room at the top of that pyramid. ■

;An assumption exists in Westminster that polls will narrow and scrutiny of Labour will increase as the election nears.到目前为止，情况恰恰相反。 Labour's polling lead remains a sturdy 20 percentage points, according to our ;tracker;. ;Glowing profiles of people who may prove useful sources at some point—“beat-sweeteners”, in the trade—come thick and fast.凯尔爵士的幕僚长苏·格雷受到了赞扬。她作为一名公务员的缺点，例如近乎反社会的对保密的渴望，被忽视了，而一些小才能却受到了赞扬。 “她在计时方面非常无情，”一张肖像指出。 Often the tone is of a primary-school teacher sending a report to a parent: “One Labour figure said Gray had been a good listener.”

;The chin of the right-wing press is also smeared with boot polish. ;When it comes to business, the boot is supposedly on the other foot: it is Labour that is trying to woo business via a “smoked salmon offensive” led by Ms Reeves.这已经倒退了。政府可以征税、监管和罚款，只需部长大笔一挥就能压垮丰厚的利润。 The best a firm can manage is a threat to close a factory in a marginal seat and to sign a letter to the ;Financial Times;.因此，当工党二月份在椭圆板球场举办每人 1,000 英镑（1,270 美元）的商业会议时，这个地方挤满了对皮革感兴趣的公共事务人士。

;Bootlicking always comes to an end.人们在政客上升时欢呼，在下降时嘘声。约翰逊先生在成为独特的负债之前是一种独特的资产。几个月内，特蕾莎·梅就从“脱欧”布迪卡变成了“Maybot”——一个出现故障的机器人。 Rishi Sunak 曾经是“Dishy Rishi”，英国最受欢迎的政治家，他用 Excel 制作数据透视表的能力让记者们眼花缭乱。 Excel 技能持续提升； the personal ratings do not.

;; T;;HE RESULTS; of the local elections held on March 31st are a milestone in Turkey's history.由于大多数地方权力现在被选民委托给政治反对派，土耳其不再没有选择。 its trajectory is firmly set towards democracy again.

;

;Despite unfair competition, especially in the allocation of state resources to the ruling party and its candidates and government control of the media, the opposition Republican People's Party (;CHP;), of which I am a member, emerged victorious.在伊斯坦布尔，政府官员和总统积极竞选支持我的对手市长选举。 We won even though other opposition parties, which had allied themselves with the ;CHP; in last year's elections, abandoned our coalition and ran their own candidates.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This victory showed that true democratic power lies in the hands of the people. This was a vote of confidence in a new form of municipal governance that we have termed the “Istanbul Model”. This model prioritises equality, civic participation in the democratic process and more effective economic and social-development policies at the local level.

;

;On March 31st voters elected social-democratic candidates not only in Istanbul and its districts but across Turkey, redrawing the electoral map. Their message is clear. From now on they want to see a country governed by the rule of law and democracy. They reject divisive policies and authoritarianism. They envision a united Turkey, not one torn apart by polarisation. Furthermore, this election result was a protest against the deepening economic crisis: soaring inflation, rising unemployment and a cost-of-living squeeze.

;

;The current government, which has held power for 22 years, has seen a loss of support from key voter groups including young people, women, blue-collar workers and pensioners. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Justice and Development (;AK;) party suffered heavy setbacks in major cities, with their support concentrated mainly in rural areas. Conversely, the ;CHP; won unprecedented support in central and eastern Anatolia, signalling a shift in political dynamics across Turkey.

;

;The electoral outcome has infused the democratic opposition with new energy. Just a year ago voters narrowly supported Mr Erdogan in the presidential election. Since then the ;CHP; has made leadership changes and launched a process to radically revamp its programme. The people of Turkey have recognised and welcomed this shift in direction. They have a strong desire for change.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The election has also shown that citizens can form much stronger alliances than political elites. Even if parties and political leaders lose hope in democracy, citizens do not. As the democrats of Turkey, we are committed to expanding this grassroots alliance. The future of Turkish democracy and the country's prosperity hinges on it.

;

;The past two decades have seen a crisis in democracy, with authoritarian governments coming to power around the world. Driven by populism and polarisation, this upheaval has stoked global uncertainties, prompting people to question whether the end of the democratic era is near.

;

;For Turkey, however, March 31st marked the opposite: the end of the erosion of democracy. It is a turning-point that carries profound implications, not only for Turkey but also for its immediate region and beyond. It shows how authoritarian tendencies can be challenged and serves as an example to the world. In many countries voters are entrenched in their partisan affiliations. Turkey has demonstrated that this need not be the case. When coherent and credible alternatives for governance are presented, voters are willing to change their preferences and reject populist authoritarianism.

;

;The task now for elected mayors, including myself, is to ensure that a common set of rules for accountable local governance is consistently implemented. This approach will require reliable internal monitoring and assessment of public services in ;CHP;-held jurisdictions.

;

;At the same time, we will look to co-operate with the government to address our cities' and the wider country's chronic problems, particularly in earthquake and disaster preparedness and management. ;

;The ;CHP; has now emerged as the strongest alternative to Mr Erdogan's ;AK; for the leadership of the country. Over the next five years social-democratic mayors will govern municipalities that account for more than 70% of Turkey's population and almost 80% of its economy. As we move towards the next presidential and parliamentary elections, changes at the local level will lay the groundwork for broader changes on the national stage.

;

;Regardless of future efforts by Mr Erdogan's populist regime, Istanbul and Turkey will stand as symbols of freedom, democracy and social harmony.以人民为先的新政治精神将战胜威权民粹主义。在经历了民主衰落和经济衰退的一代人之后，土耳其共和国带着对民主的新信心进入了第二个世纪。 ;■;

;;S;;有时它只是一个气球。或者它可能是一架无人机。有些高速行驶并改变方向；有些则高速行驶。其他人徘徊，然后消失。传感器检测到其中一些。其他人则在雷达下飞行。数十年来，不明飞行物（;UFO;）一直是流行传说的一部分，但各国政府最近一直在努力弄清楚什么是幻想，什么是事实。私营企业开始众包;UFO;数据，希望为政府和其他机构提供可以调查的证据。

;;;

;Enigma Labs 是一家成立于 2020 年的私营公司，提供一款为用户提供支持的应用上传;UFO;的图像，以及有关它们的描述和其他数据。在过去 18 个月中，它已收到约 15,000 份提交材料（参见地图 1）。 Enigma 使用机器学习和人类主持人来评估这些内容。据估计，大约三分之二是不明异常现象（<小>;UAP;），这是<小>;UFO;的新说法，摆脱了旧术语“小绿人”的包袱。换句话说，它们存在但很神秘。

;;

;;UAP; 有多种尺寸和形状，尽管圆形和球体是最常见的（见图表）。十分之一的目击者报告了异常的飞行模式，例如高速时不稳定的运动。近三分之一的人表示，他们没有看到任何迹象表明他们拥有推进装置，例如喷气式排气装置。 Enigma 表示，超过一半的目击事件中有多名目击者，这有助于增加可信度。

;;
;;;
;

;Enigma 的应用程序仅提供英文版本，所以这并不奇怪目击事件集中在英语国家，尤其是美国。新墨西哥州脱颖而出（参见地图 2）。在美国各州中，其报告的 ;UAP; 数量与其人口比例最高（就目击数量而言，加利福尼亚州名列前茅）。新墨西哥州长期以来一直是<小>;不明飞行物;目击事件的热点地区，这引发了古怪的阴谋论。 Enigma 的数据表明，三种可能性之一是正确的：该州的人们准备好寻找<小>;不明飞行物;；该地区有某种特质，使其成为看起来像<小>;UFO;的现象高度集中的地方；或者说这些理论毕竟并没有那么奇怪。 
;
;Enigma 的早期采用者似乎是您可能希望留意的那种人。在 2,000 多名表明自己职业的用户中，一半以上是其国家武装部队的前任或现任成员或民用飞行员（见图表）。但该公司希望，随着<小>;不明飞行物;的发现变得更加受人尊敬，其目击者的基础将会扩大。
;
;最近，美国国会罕见地获得了两党对调查UFO的支持。一名前情报官员告诉 ; 2023 年的国会听证会指出政府窝藏非人类“生物制品”。在同一事件中，一位退休海军指挥官作证说，水手和飞行员追踪到的物体的能力似乎“远远优于”武装部队所拥有的技术。 （五角大楼在三月份发布了一份报告，结论是没有证据表明存在“外星技术”，尽管一些;UAP;的起源仍然是个谜。）;NASA;，美国太空该机构最近任命了 UAP 研究总监。该组织负责人比尔·尼尔森 (Bill Nelson) 表示，讨论需要“从耸人听闻转向科学”。无论;UAP;是什么，它们都会给空中交通带来安全问题：美国飞行员报告了几次险些发生的事故。

;

;不出所料，这个领域吸引了很多关注，但并非都是积极的。因此，Enigma 的工作人员更愿意保持匿名。例如，他们的工作可以检测航空航天技术或政府监视计划的机密进展。或者它可能有助于解释自然界中的某些事物，例如天气或空间现象。外星人猎人会有他们自己的理论。该公司的老板（只用“<小>;A;”）告诉;《经济学人》;，她的员工是“理性的问题解决者”，他们将去“数据引导的任何地方”。 ;■;

;;A; ;十年前; 金融各部委陷入紧缩热潮。即使失业率高企、经济增长疲软，各国政府仍竭尽全力削减预算赤字。今天，情况已大不相同。在整个西方，大多数经济体的状况都较好。人们有工作。企业利润增长强劲。然而，各国政府的支出远远超过其收入。

;

;没有哪个政府比美国政府更加挥霍。今年，这个世界最大经济体的预算赤字（支出超过税收）预计将超过;GDP;的 7%，这一水平在经济衰退和战时之外是闻所未闻的。但它并不是唯一一个挥霍无度的国家。爱沙尼亚和芬兰这两个一向节俭的北欧国家目前正面临巨额预算赤字。继2007-09年全球金融危机之后，去年意大利的赤字规模与2010-11年一样大，而法国的赤字占;GDP;的比例增长至5.5%，远高于预测。财政部长布鲁诺·勒梅尔上个月宣布：“我呼吁集体敲响警钟，让我们在所有公共支出中做出选择。”

;;
;;
;

;一些国家比较保守。去年塞浦路斯出现盈余。希腊和葡萄牙——接近平衡预算——看起来像是财政廉洁的典范，尽管它们仍然背负着巨额债务。尽管如此，总体方向还是明确的。 ;《经济学人》;分析了 35 个富裕国家的数据。 2017-19 年，我们样本中的中等国家;;实现了预算盈余，而去年的预算赤字接近 ;GDP ;的 2.5%（见图 1）。 “主要”赤字（不包括利息支付）和“结构性”赤字（脱离经济周期）的衡量标准也急剧扩大。

;
;
;< div id="econ-1" class="adComponent_adcontainer__eooQr">;
;
;
;

;有两个因素解释了这种挥霍行为。第一个与税收有关。在整个富裕国家，收入出人意料地疲弱。在美国，去年从工资中扣除的所得税收入略有下降。与此同时，“非预扣所得税”，包括资本利得税，下降了四分之一。英国的资本利得税收入比近期高点低了 11%。日本本财年的自我评估税（包括一些资本利得税）预计将比去年低 4%。

;

;由于 2022 年底和 2023 年初的市场动荡，税务人员正在遭受苦难。支付高薪的科技公司解雇了员工，削减了所得税。随着股价下跌，家庭和投资者出售股票以获取利润变得更加困难，从而减少了资本收益池。去年，随着房价下跌，很少有人通过炒房赚钱。私募股权公司的高级员工通常以投资回报而非传统工资的形式获得收入，今年过得很糟糕。

;

;第二个因素是国家支出。继新冠肺炎 (covid-19) 大流行期间采取了不择手段的财政政策后，各国政府已经紧缩，但并未完全紧缩。在澳大利亚，养老院的老年人在新冠疫情爆发期间仍可能获得经济援助。直到 2023 年中期，德国才完全取消了疫情期间实施的就业保护计划。美国仍在向小企业支付大量退税，这些企业在封锁期间让人们继续工作。在意大利，2020 年制定的一个旨在鼓励房主绿色家园的项目已经失控，政府迄今已支付了价值 2000 亿欧元的支持（或占 ;GDP; 的 10%）。其中一项计划的名称“Superbonus”如果不是那么挥霍的话，会很有趣。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;政客们也变得更愿意进行干预并花钱——为了纠正感知到的错误。俄罗斯入侵乌克兰、能源价格飙升后，欧洲各国政府拨出约 4% 的 GDP 来保护家庭和企业免受影响。包括波兰和波罗的海国家在内的一些国家现在在枪支和士兵上投入巨资。乔·拜登总统希望在 11 月美国总统大选之前尽可能多地免除学生债务。

;

;消防水带还能喷多久？乍一看，似乎还能持续一段时间。市场大幅上涨，这将增加税收收入。政府的债务可持续性不会仅仅因为预算赤字的变化而改变。它也是总体公共债务、经济增长、通货膨胀和利率的产物。自疫情结束以来，通货膨胀率一直很高，经济增长也很稳健。尽管费率有所上升，但按照历史标准来看仍然相当低。

;
;;
;

;这些条件使政治家处于财政最佳位置（请参阅图2）。我们计算出，在2022 - 23年，中位数国家的主要赤字约为; gdp ;的2％，并且仍然削减了其公共 - debt-to- ; gdp ;比率; 。债务的名义价值将会上升，但是，在通货膨胀的帮助下，经济规模将会增加。意大利的债务比率下降了约十个百分点，尽管其财政政策松散，但; GDP ;从2021年的峰值下降了。法国的这一比例也有所下降。希腊 - 将有利的经济状况与严格的财政政策相结合 - 已经看到其债务与; GDP ;比率下降了一个惊人的50个百分点。

; ; < p data-component =“段落” class =“ CSS-1F0X4SL E1TT35BK0”>;现在正在改变。尽管经济增长和通胀下降，但政府面临的利率尚未下降。这已经让财政算术变得更加令人畏惧。例如，根据我们的计算，根据我们的计算，意大利政府的主要地位与稳定的债务比率一致，这已经从去年的; GDP ;的赤字下降到了这一赤字，而在这一量中的盈余量下降了2％。美国的处境非常相似。通货膨胀率进一步下降，增长率下降或更高的利率将使政府仍然难以稳定其债务。

;

; eu ;的立场将很快受到谴责。在英国，希望不久之后掌权的反对党工党承诺实施财政整顿。法国政府谈论削减医疗支出和失业救济金。美国是个例外。在世界领先的经济体中，谈话仍然没有转变。大选前，唐纳德·特朗普和拜登承诺为数百万选民减税。但财政逻辑是无情的。无论他们喜欢与否，政客挥霍无度的时代都将结束。 ;■;
